neutron_lib/placement/client.py.message:
I think this is problematic.

Imagine that you have an allocation of 10 and you want to increase that by 2. In the current code the update_allocation() needs to be called with 12 so that the update result in the increase of 2. BUT if the allocation is changed in the meantime e.g. maybe decreased to 5 by somebody else, then this update will set the allocation to 12, instead of 5 + 2 = 7. You have to apply the change instead of apply the end result.

In qos specific case, I think, three things can happen with an allocation while you are trying to update it here:

a) The whole allocation is deleted by Nova as the VM is deleted in parallel.

b) The whole allocation is moved from one RP tree to another as the VM is migrated to another host in parallel

c) The value of the specific BW allocation you are trying to update is changed in parallel. E.g A port is detached from the instance that allocated BW from the same device RP you try to update or a new port is attached to the VM that consumes BW from the same device RP you try to update here.

All three cases can happen between the port update request and  your first reading the allocation from placement here and also when you re-read the allocation after a generation conflict is encountered and you retry the loop.

You can detect a) by the fact that placement returns an empty allocation for a non exiting consumer. In this case I think you have to reject the qos update.

stack@aio:/opt/stack/nova$ openstack --os-placement-api-version 1.28  resource provider allocation show nonexitent -f json
[]

In case of b) you will detect the move by the fact that the rp_uuid you try to find in the allocation does not exists (as it is moved to another RP of another host). I think you have to either reject the qos update, or have to re-read your port data from the DB as the rp_uuid has been changed in the binding profile due to the move.

In case of c) you don't have to bail out but you have to (re-)apply your logic to the allocation you got from placement. E.g. you have to increase or decrease the new BW allocation. (Instead of blindly overwriting it)

There is a special case for c), when the port that you are handling here is the one that is being detached from the VM in parallel. I don't think you can easily detect that just by looking at the placement allocation as other non detached ports could consume from the same device RP. But also I'm not sure if that can even happen from neutron perspective that a port is being updated from two different sources at the same time (e.g. port update by nova to unbound, and port update by the end user to update qos on the port)
Thanks Gibi for the detailed description, I come with new patch as soon as possible (locally it works already, but I have to clean it)
yepp, this is what I wanted to see :)
Wondering if we want to leave some breadcrumbs (i.e. debug log lines about the retry) for helping the troubleshooting.
This is unnecessary. Catching an re-raising is the same as simply not catching and letting it propagate up the callstack.

nit, out of context: we "really" need a restfull call to "update" (increase/decrease) an allocation, instead of reading the current value and sending the updated one.

With a restfull (and atomic) operation, you don't need to worry about having a possible update conflict.
At this point we can assume that there was not enough inventory for the request. I guess upper layers will handle this case.
yes, that part will be in neutron side code
super nit: This kind of new lines is tricky. Perhaps we can assign a variable and then use it in the if clause. Of course it is not a blcoker.

nit: one could also write more concise:

    self._types = [] if types is None else types

For the record, I think mutable defaults are fine in cases like this where we know the lifecycle of the variables.  I wouldn't have asked for this change.  But in general it's obviously better, so I don't object to it either.  Having said that, since the entire goal of this change is to avoid human programming errors, we should endeavor to avoid creating a new type of error by creating a wall of text that is difficult to read and verify.  How about we use this form instead:

self._types = types or []

That seems more readable to me and therefore easier to verify.

 wsgi.is_accepting = False

This evaluates / but then creates an image within /var/lib.  It's (remotely) possible /var is on another disk or partition.  Should evaluate the proper destination.
Oops. Then no need in it.
Actually, looks like -P is mutually exclusive with --output.  Since --output=avail will only print the number, is there still a need for -P?

Note, there would still be an assumption in this math that containers (/var/lib) and images (/opt) are sharing the same filesystem, which is true (/) for our current setup.  We could change the ironic image location /var/lib/something to help with this.

An alternative bit of math that would deal with ironic and containers being on different filesystems would be to simply check whether Total RAM is >=32GB -- this is an equivalent check, since

(Total Free Disk) = (Total RAM * .7) - (Other Stuff on RAM Disk(s))
Other Stuff on RAM Disk(s) ~= 5.5GB

Do we want this rewrite to be inclusive of the case where the available system memory is so large (e.g. in this case, > than NEED_MB) that this isn't even relevant and you can avoid any kind of local storage binding?

On a 256/384G system, the available RAM would likely be > than 16384MB making this rather moot.

Said differently to be more clear, its almost like all of this voodoo is only engaged if you don't think the available memory is sufficient to support some level of container/image needs, and 16G seems like a reasonable place to draw that line.
i'd say we should not really care about mount points if we have enough RAM according to condition on L112

It's basically to give a chance for do post conversion for async actions. For async actions the result gets delivered by a 3rd party but we still may want to do some post-run transformation. Consider an ad-hoc action. It has the section "output" that can apply some transformation for the result of the base action, which is delivered by an external system (or human). I think it would be better if this was standardized. I like the current quasi scheme with "std." We can also make "openstack.heat.someaction" Do we really see the need for this level of flexibility?

Aah, it's declared this way because I tried to imagine how different providers could work and I realised that on one hand we need to have this backwards compatibility around std.xxx actions and all other actions named something like cbnd.xxx or cbam.xxx delivered in the old way via the entry point "mistral.actions". I found it very convenient to have just one action provider responsible for the legacy way of delivering actions via the entry point. So it means that in this case one provider will be responsible for more than one quasi namespace like "std" or something else. On the other hand I want to give a chance to other implementations to use it in a more tricky way so that, for example, we could change a namespace for all the actions of a certain provider just by changing one string in setup.cfg (the left part of the string "foobar = my_project.my_cool_action_provider").

devstack-vm-gate.sh.message:
Instead of this would it be possible to trigger a ring rebuild after the subnode deploys? (even if that means we've built the ring twice?)

Because the node build order today is:

 - build primary completely
 - build subnodes one at a time

And changing that order is going to make other things complicated.

Well, not without some possible side effects.

When the primary node gets deployed, some data will be alredy stored in Swift (an image upload). So if we change the ring later on we need to wait until replicators moved all data from the primary node to the subnode, otherwise it will become unavailable. However, I'm not sure if this is used later on in Tempest? We could give it a try.

What we could do is to include both the primary and subnode in the ring, and later stop the storage services on the primary.

cmd/root.go.message: I'd propose to introduce singleton log object in main.go ans therefore we can avoid parent prerun functions execution

I agree with Dmitry. We can totally avoid using PersistentPreRun here. Instead we could make log.Init method lazy and call it inside pkg/log module. And here in the cmd module we could just set couple log variables (one for output and another for debug).  Since log initialization is lazy, then these output and debug variables will have been already set (directly or from PersistentFlags). 

This will allow us to delete all these ugly lines 
```
			if parentPreRun := cmd.Root().PersistentPreRun; parentPreRun != nil {
				parentPreRun(cmd.Root(), args)
			}
```

I just want to lodge my opinion that unenforced type annotations are harmful, IMHO. In addition to hurting readability (yes really), if they're wrong they're actively confusing the reader. I'm sure everyone else loves them but me, but I definitely would vote to not have them in here.

> I just want to lodge my opinion that unenforced type annotations
 > are harmful, IMHO. In addition to hurting readability (yes really),
 > if they're wrong they're actively confusing the reader. I'm sure
 > everyone else loves them but me, but I definitely would vote to not

The same argument can and has been made about comments in general. See "good code is self-documenting". We're not going to settle such philosophical debates in Gerrit comments, but I'll note that the plan is that we eventually will enforce all of these hints. Some are already enforced, in fact. For example, try to call 'nova.crypto.generate_fingerprint' with a bytestring or other non-string argument from a file and function that has type checking enabled right now and run mypy on that [1][2]. It has to be incremental though, because no one's going to review a giant patch to add type hints to everything in one fell swoop, and I seriously doubt I'd even be able to churn that out in a remotely reasonable time.

nova/compute/resource_tracker.py.message: So in the case of a different-node resize this whole block is skipped...
But we enter this block (on the source)
But then this gives us None, because by this time, the old flavor has been removed from the instance object.

And this entire blocked never gets executed.

What I don't get is - how does any of this cause the periodic task to free up the instance's PCPUs? Because that's what I assume is happening, right? The periodic frees it up, and when we get to the drop_move_claim at the end of the confirm_resize, we attempt to unpin CPUs that are no longer pinned.

In reply to the comment on line 1300, this is the issue. Remember, when we say "unpin" in this context, we're not actually do anything with libvirt - it's purely resource tracking. Because we don't enter this 'if itype:' block, we never call '_update_usage'. As I highlighted above, that's responsible for increasing the usage of the 'ComputeNode.numa_topology' for the instance via a call to 'hardware.numa_usage_from_instance_numa'. If that happens, the usage gets out of whack
Ah, we don't "delta" the usage, we rebuild it from scratch every time. So if a certain migration/instance doesn't get counted as "tracked", it'll effectively unpin its PCPUs.

I was under the impression that as long as hw:numa_nodes=1 is not explicitly set and if there are no associated PCI/SRIOV affinity involved then a multi vcpu instance can pin cross NUMA, is that not valid? Also what is the suggested deployment approach in the field? Is it all pCPUs from say N NUMA different nodes are allocated as dedicated or would each NUMA node be broken up as X for host, Y for dedicated, and Z for shared?  Or is it simply each customer has their own approach?

> Done, per advice on line 790.  Do you mind clarifying a couple
 > things though. I was under the impression that as long as
 > hw:numa_nodes=1 is not explicitly set and if there are no
 > associated PCI/SRIOV affinity involved then a multi vcpu instance
 > can pin cross NUMA, is that not valid?

An instance's NUMA node will always be pinned to a single host NUMA node, and an instance will get a NUMA topology if you either enable it explicitly (through that 'hw:numa_nodes' extra spec) or implicitly (through use of CPU pinning, hugepages, or vPMEM). In this case, I'm concerned about the pinned case. 

 > Also what is the suggested
 > deployment approach in the field? Is it all pCPUs from say N NUMA
 > different nodes are allocated as dedicated or would each NUMA node
 > be broken up as X for host, Y for dedicated, and Z for shared?  Or
 > is it simply each customer has their own approach?

Very much per customer. We normally recommend at least the first core (+ thread sibling) on each socket is reserved for the host but until now, it wasn't possible have pinned and unpinned cores on the same host. Now, I guess the only hard advice we'd have is to continue reserving the first cores for the host and to make sure you don't assign a core to one set (e.g. shared) and its thread sibling to another (e.g. dedicated)

This seems overly complicated and could prove problematic as noted above. Could just simply assign half of our cores to dedicated and half to shared? For multi-node hosts, that would likely mean one or two sockets for each, while for single node hosts that would me literally half of the CPUs. We can get the node information from 'NUMAClient.get_host_topology' so something as trivial as:


    def get_cpu_sets():
        topology = numaclient.get_host_topology()
        if len(topology) == 1:  # single-node host, split the node
            cpu_shared_set = set(topology[0][:len(topology[0])//2])
            cpu_dedicated_set = set(topology[0][len(topology[0])//2:])
        else:  # multi-node host, use the first two nodes
            cpu_shared_set = set(topology[0])
            cpu_dedicated_set = set(topology[1])

        assert len(cpu_shared_set) >= 2
        assert len(cpu_dedicated_set) >= 2

        return cpu_shared_set, cpu_dedicated_set

This would mean setting different values on each host but that's not a bad thing for users whose compute hosts are homogeneous

  True
You can do this w/ oslo_utils.versionutils is_compatible().

Sorry that I forgot about oslo versionutils.  I agree with Eric that it's better to use those (because they'll make sure if the underlying library changes, the oslo utils will remain stable).  Also, it has a "same_major" parameter that will make it easy to fix the case where ceph P goes back to the old-style config.  

  >>> from oslo_utils import versionutils
  >>> OCTOPUS_BASE_VERSION="15.2.0"
  >>> versionutils.is_compatible(OCTOPUS_BASE_VERSION, "15.11.1")
  True
  >>> versionutils.is_compatible(OCTOPUS_BASE_VERSION, "14.11.1")
  False
  >>> versionutils.is_compatible(OCTOPUS_BASE_VERSION, "16.11.1")
  False
  >>> versionutils.is_compatible(OCTOPUS_BASE_VERSION, "16.11.1", same_major=False)
  True

So yeah, that's a not so subtle nudge to define the base version at the top of the file.  And also, I apologize for including the python output above, but the order of parameters in oslo versionutils was the opposite of what I was expecting, so I thought it might be helpful to point that out.
No worries :)  If it makes the code better, I'm all for it.  I'll update the patch with the suggestion above.  thanks!

The default for 'same_major' is True, so this call will return False when we hit ceph 16.x.0.  So I guess the question is, do we think it likely that ceph P will go back to the config without '[general]', or will '[general]' be required from O onwards?

That's an intriguing default.  I guess it's meant to be "only compatible with this version by default", which is fair enough.  I think this is a breaking change going forwards, so I'll change the 'same_major' to False.  I'll be testing with the next version of Ceph anyway, so I'll hopefully pickup any further changes as they come in.

Since this comment needs to be fixed anyway, I think it would be a good idea to add:  By setting same_major=False below, we are betting that this change will also be required for releases after octopus.

There are a few things in flight here. For now I hope to keep the number of haproxy processes running at 1 per namespace. But we'll need to fine tune the header mangling too which may or may not force us to switch to 2 per namespace. In the latter case we could narrow the bind.

Now we got rid of this.

This will introduce a regression since we've been removing the "any" address and replacing with a specific one - https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1745618

It's almost like it needs to bind each address separately if IPv6 is enabled.

With some help I finally understood the root cause of this problem. IPv6 Duplicate Address Detection made the address unusable (still in tentative state) in the first few seconds after we configured it. That's why haproxy couldn't bind(). Now I added code to explicitly wait until DAD completes, so we shouldn't see this problem again.

Sorry for the slow progress here. After I made the change locally to make haproxy listen explicitly on 169.254.169.254:80 and [fe80::a9fe:a9fe]:80 I started to notice thay haproxy could not start with the error message "Starting proxy listener: cannot bind socket [fe80::a9fe:a9fe:80]". It took me quite a lot of time to debug this and now I believe we have a bug either in pyroute2 (or something under pyroute2) or in the way we use pyroute2 (from neutron). For details please see here:

https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/issues/721

Until that gets solved I think I'll add some workaround (sleep or waiting until the address appears) to this change series soon, so we can progress here.

One more note here: In the router namespace haproxy alywas did and does listen on the wildcard address. At least it definitely cannot listen on the metadata addresses (v4 or v6) since those are not configured in the router namespace. Theoretically it could listen on a concrete IP instead where we DNAT the metadata traffic to.

But to be honest I never fully understood bug #1745618, because in my understanding we expose the exact same (potentially sensitve) data on all the IPs we bind to. Therefore I don't see how it is unsafe to read some data over a semi-random IP when the same data is safe to read over the metadata IP (where the reader is identified the same way in both cases).

I understand that giving wider-than-necessary access to potentially sensitive data is not good practice, but I don't see how this is a security bug in itself.

I wanted to mention this, but please note that this change series didn't change this behavior in the router namespace. If we think haproxy listening on a wildcard address in the router namespace is a bug, maybe we better handle that as a standalone bug and change.

os_brick/tests/initiator/connectors/test.message:
The reason why this fails in Python 2.7 and not 3.x seems to have to do with the different behavior of the call to `thread.start()`.

In Python 3.7 it's immediately starting the code in this file's line 1225-1231, but in 2.7 it doesn't start until eventlet decides to, which is not immediately since the sleep is mocked.

Solution is to either change this call to:

  self.assertGreaterEqual(get_wwn_mock.call_count, 2)

In this case we don't know how long it'll take for it to finish, though in 100 test runs the average test run was 0.0054 seconds.

The other solution is to `import time` and create a global variable to store the sleep method `ORIGINAL_SLEEP = time.sleep` and then call it as a side effect on L1220: `@mock.patch('time.sleep', side_effect=lambda x: ORIGINAL_SLEEP(0.001))`.

In 100 test runs this averaged to 0.0072 seconds each run.

diskimage_builder/elements/package-insta.message:
this reads better as:
if 'uninstall' in param

I wonder if it shouldn't have actually been just: 'build-only' in param

or without this condition at all - just make all permanent installs permanent

It preserves the "install" side of the old behavior. The old datastructure we have is something like:

  packages:
    install:
      - (git, element1)
      - (vim, element1)
      - (git, element2)
    uninstall:
      - (emacs, element1)
      - (git, element2)

What I am trying to preserve here is that (git, element2) remains in the install list even if it isn't in the uninstall list. That said I do think you are right that this isn't strictly necessary as git is already present and we know we don't want to uninstall it.

I'm not familiar enough with the package installs element to know how important the element by element listing even for duplicate packages is. If it isn't very important then I agree we can probably make the change you suggest.

Well, it does not really preserve the old behaviour, as that would be ["install", "uninstall"]. I still argue that it reads better as I wrote above as this is an equivalent condition under the common 'if'. Or even without this condition.

The reason this is 'build-only' not in param is that the old code checked both and not exclusively. That means we only want to do a full skip if build-only is not set. If uninstall and build-only are set we don't want to skip and want to process with just installs = ['install'] to preserve the old behavior.

OK, you want to preserve duplicate installs, as in the new code the above "old" would become (with current code):

  packages:
    install:
      - (git, element1)
      - (vim, element1)
      - (git, element2)
    uninstall:
      - (emacs, element1)

as opposed to:

  packages:
    install:
      - (git, element1)
      - (vim, element1)
    uninstall:
      - (emacs, element1)

It is actually kind of important, yes, as elements have their own pkg maps.
It would be confusing to see them apply different maps but that is a problem for another day. :-)

'here' I guess; it must have been tried 'elsewhere' if we can remove it

Is this branch for optimisation?

No this is required beause we don't control the order or processing of the individual package files. The two test cases added in this change try to capture that as well.

We have the case where we try to set build-only or uninstall on a package that is already explicitly only installed (thats the first block). Then we have the second case where something set build-only or uninstall then we find a second case that is install only (this case).
Makes sense, thank you. I missed the lack of control over ordering.
